content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <feed xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">   <title>LRA Collection:</title>   <link rel="alternate" href="http://hdl.handle.net/2381/9823" />   <subtitle />   <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2381/9823</id>   <updated>2015-03-15T23:01:10Z</updated>   <dc:date>2015-03-15T23:01:10Z</dc:date>   <entry>     <title>Ferritic and Martensitic Steels for Power Plants</title>     <link rel="alternate" href="http://hdl.handle.net/2381/31431" />     <author>       <name>Ennis, Philip J.</name>     </author>     <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2381/31431</id>     <updated>2015-01-17T02:01:47Z</updated>     <published>2015-01-16T11:57:03Z</published>     <summary type="text">Title: Ferritic and Martensitic Steels for Power Plants Authors: Ennis, Philip J. Editors: Shirdazi, A; Jackson, S Abstract: The metallurgical background and the physical properties of the steels used in power plant are briefly described. The microstructures of the steels after the production heat treatment and after long-term service exposure are discussed and the mechanical properties, especially the creep rupture strength, are shown. The strengthening mechanisms are considered and effects of the microstructural changes after long-term service exposure on the creep rupture strength explained. Because of the microstructural changes, care has to be taken in deriving long-term creep rupture strength estimates from experimental data. It is shown that steam oxidation may be a significant life-limiting factor for thin section components operating at temperatures around 600 o C. Description: The file associated with this record is embargoed.</summary>     <dc:date>2015-01-16T11:57:03Z</dc:date>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Nickel-Base Alloys for Advanced Power Plant Components</title>     <link rel="alternate" href="http://hdl.handle.net/2381/31430" />     <author>       <name>Ennis, Philip J.</name>     </author>     <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2381/31430</id>     <updated>2015-01-17T02:01:47Z</updated>     <published>2015-01-16T11:55:56Z</published>     <summary type="text">Title: Nickel-Base Alloys for Advanced Power Plant Components Authors: Ennis, Philip J. Editors: Shibli, Ahmed Abstract: The materials requirements for advanced steam power plant operating at steam temperatures of 700 oC are described and it is shown that several nickel-base alloys that were developed for gas turbine components are suitable candidate alloys. The materials testing programmes underway to qualify these alloys for steam power plant applications are summarised. The physical and mechanical properties of selected alloys (Alloys 230, 617, 263, 718Plus and 740) are discussed. For the alloys 617 and 740, modifications have been proposed to optimise performance at temperatures around 700 oC. The microstructural stability, steam oxidation resistance and fabrication issues in the production of large components are also considered. Description: The file associated with this record is embargoed.</summary>     <dc:date>2015-01-16T11:55:56Z</dc:date>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Improved Odour Detection through Imposed Biomimetic Temporal Dynamics</title>     <link rel="alternate" href="http://hdl.handle.net/2381/28878" />     <author>       <name>Pearce, Timothy Charles</name>     </author>     <author>       <name>Sanchez Montanes, MA</name>     </author>     <author>       <name>Gardner, JW</name>     </author>     <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2381/28878</id>     <updated>2014-06-23T13:45:00Z</updated>     <published>2014-05-28T14:00:28Z</published>     <summary type="text">Title: Improved Odour Detection through Imposed Biomimetic Temporal Dynamics Authors: Pearce, Timothy Charles; Sanchez Montanes, MA; Gardner, JW Editors: Gutierrez, A; Marco, S</summary>     <dc:date>2014-05-28T14:00:28Z</dc:date>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Handbook of Machine Olfaction</title>     <link rel="alternate" href="http://hdl.handle.net/2381/28871" />     <author>       <name />     </author>     <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2381/28871</id>     <updated>2014-06-23T13:45:32Z</updated>     <published>2014-05-28T13:52:24Z</published>     <summary type="text">Title: Handbook of Machine Olfaction Editors: Pearce, Timothy Charles; Gardner, JW; Nagle, HT; Schiffman, HT</summary>     <dc:date>2014-05-28T13:52:24Z</dc:date>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Special Issue of Reviews in the Neurosciences, Proceedings the European Network of Neuroinformatics Workshop on Neural and Artificial Computation`</title>     <link rel="alternate" href="http://hdl.handle.net/2381/28868" />     <author>       <name>Pearce,Timothy Charles</name>     </author>     <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2381/28868</id>     <updated>2014-06-23T13:52:15Z</updated>     <published>2014-05-28T13:42:15Z</published>     <summary type="text">Title: Special Issue of Reviews in the Neurosciences, Proceedings the European Network of Neuroinformatics Workshop on Neural and Artificial Computation` Authors: Pearce,Timothy Charles Editors: Vershure, PFMJ; Pearce, TC; Keonig, P</summary>     <dc:date>2014-05-28T13:42:15Z</dc:date>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Improved odour detection through imposed biomimetic temporal dynamics</title>     <link rel="alternate" href="http://hdl.handle.net/2381/28857" />     <author>       <name>Pearce, Timothy Charles</name>     </author>     <author>       <name>Sanchez Montanes, Manuel A.</name>     </author>     <author>       <name>Gardner, Julian W.</name>     </author>     <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2381/28857</id>     <updated>2014-06-23T13:45:56Z</updated>     <published>2014-05-28T13:09:43Z</published>     <summary type="text">Title: Improved odour detection through imposed biomimetic temporal dynamics Authors: Pearce, Timothy Charles; Sanchez Montanes, Manuel A.; Gardner, Julian W. Editors: Guti\ufffd\ufffdrrez, A; Marco, S Abstract: We discuss a biomimetic approach for improving odour detection in artificial olfactory systems that utilises temporal dynamical delivery of odours to chemical sensor arrays deployed within stationary phase materials. This novel odour analysis technology, which we have termed an artificial mucosa, uses the principle of \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdnasal chromatography\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd; thus emulating the action of the mucous coating the olfactory epithelium. Temporal segregation of odorants due to selective phase partitioning during delivery in turn gives rise to complex spatio-temporal dynamics in the responses of the sensor array population, which we have exploited for enhanced detection performance. We consider the challenge of extracting stimulus-specific information from such responses, which requires specialised time-dependent signal processing, information measures and classification techniques. Description: Full text of this item is not currently available on the LRA.  The final published version may be available through the links above.</summary>     <dc:date>2014-05-28T13:09:43Z</dc:date>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Calculating Concurrency Using Circus</title>     <link rel="alternate" href="http://hdl.handle.net/2381/28129" />     <author>       <name>McEwan, Alistair A.</name>     </author>     <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2381/28129</id>     <updated>2013-10-11T10:43:41Z</updated>     <published>2013-09-04T09:56:36Z</published>     <summary type="text">Title: Calculating Concurrency Using Circus Authors: McEwan, Alistair A. Editors: Alexander, M.; Gardner, W.</summary>     <dc:date>2013-09-04T09:56:36Z</dc:date>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Molecular Dynamics Simulation and Conductivity Mechanism in Fast Ionic Crystals Based on Hollandite NaxCrxTi8-xO16</title>     <link rel="alternate" href="http://hdl.handle.net/2381/10349" />     <author>       <name>Khoo, Kien Ling</name>     </author>     <author>       <name>Dissado, Len A.</name>     </author>     <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2381/10349</id>     <updated>2013-04-08T13:35:57Z</updated>     <published>2012-04-17T14:13:51Z</published>     <summary type="text">Title: Molecular Dynamics Simulation and Conductivity Mechanism in Fast Ionic Crystals Based on Hollandite NaxCrxTi8-xO16 Authors: Khoo, Kien Ling; Dissado, Len A. Editors: Wang, Lichang</summary>     <dc:date>2012-04-17T14:13:51Z</dc:date>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Sliding-Mode Observers</title>     <link rel="alternate" href="http://hdl.handle.net/2381/9826" />     <author>       <name>Edwards, Christopher</name>     </author>     <author>       <name>Spurgeon, Sarah K.</name>     </author>     <author>       <name>Tan, Chee Pin</name>     </author>     <author>       <name>Patel, Nitin</name>     </author>     <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2381/9826</id>     <updated>2011-11-07T16:26:27Z</updated>     <published>2011-11-07T16:25:06Z</published>     <summary type="text">Title: Sliding-Mode Observers Authors: Edwards, Christopher; Spurgeon, Sarah K.; Tan, Chee Pin; Patel, Nitin Abstract: The focus of much of the research in the area of control systems theory during the seventies and eighties addressed the issue of robustness - i.e., designing controllers with the ability to maintain stability and performance in the presence of discrepancies between the plant and model. One nonlinear approach to robust controller design which emerged during this period is the Variable Structure Control Systems methodology. Variable Structure Control Systems evolved from the pioneering work in Russia of Emel\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdyanov and Barbashin in the early 1960\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds. The ideas did not appear outside the Soviet Union until the mid 1970\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds when a book by Itkis [20] and a survey paper by Utkin [29] were published in English. Variable structure systems concepts have subsequently been utilized in the design of robust regulators, model-reference systems, adaptive schemes, tracking systems and state observers. The ideas have successfully been applied to problems as diverse as automatic flight control, control of electrical motors, chemical processes, helicopter stability augmentation, space systems and robotics [12, 23, 28, 30]. Description: Metadata only entry.</summary>     <dc:date>2011-11-07T16:25:06Z</dc:date>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Circumventing the Relative Degree Condition in Sliding Mode Design</title>     <link rel="alternate" href="http://hdl.handle.net/2381/9825" />     <author>       <name>Edwards, Christopher</name>     </author>     <author>       <name>Floquet, Thierry</name>     </author>     <author>       <name>Spurgeon, Sarah K.</name>     </author>     <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2381/9825</id>     <updated>2011-11-07T16:08:16Z</updated>     <published>2011-11-07T16:05:56Z</published>     <summary type="text">Title: Circumventing the Relative Degree Condition in Sliding Mode Design Authors: Edwards, Christopher; Floquet, Thierry; Spurgeon, Sarah K. Abstract: A continuous time sliding mode is generated by means of discontinuities in the applied injection signals, about a surface in the state space [17, 33, 40]. The discontinuity surface (usually known as the sliding surface) is attained from any initial condition ideally in a finite time interval. Provided the injection signals are designed appropriately, the motion when constrained to the surface (the sliding mode) is completely insensitive to so-called matched uncertainties, i.e. uncertainties that lie within the range space of the matrix distributing the injection signals. Much early work in this area related to control problems and assumed all of the states were available for use both in the switching function evaluation and also by the control law. For practical application however, the case when only limited state information is available is of interest. Description: Metadata only entry.</summary>     <dc:date>2011-11-07T16:05:56Z</dc:date>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Advances in Variable Structure and Sliding Mode Control</title>     <link rel="alternate" href="http://hdl.handle.net/2381/9824" />     <author>       <name>Edwards, Christopher</name>     </author>     <author>       <name>Fossas Colet, Enric</name>     </author>     <author>       <name>Fridman, Leonid</name>     </author>     <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2381/9824</id>     <updated>2011-11-07T15:47:06Z</updated>     <published>2011-11-07T15:44:47Z</published>     <summary type="text">Title: Advances in Variable Structure and Sliding Mode Control Authors: Edwards, Christopher; Fossas Colet, Enric; Fridman, Leonid Abstract: Sliding Mode Control is recognized as an efficient tool to design controllers which are robust with respect to uncertainty. The resulting controllers have low sensitivity to plant parameters and perturbations and allow the possibility of decoupling the original plant system into two components of lower dimension. In addition many controllers ensure finite time convergence to the switching surface and can be straightforwardly implemented. However, in addition to this traditional area of exploitation, sliding mode concepts are being increasingly deployed for the design of observers for estimation and identification.  Many of the chapters in this book are based on expansions of selected presentations from the 8th IEEE International Workshop on Variable Structure Systems VSS'04, which was held in Barcelona, Spain in September 2004. The editors have tried to identify the key contributions from this workshop, which define the state-of-the-art, represent new directions building on existing work, and highlight new emerging application areas. Description: Metadata only entry</summary>     <dc:date>2011-11-07T15:44:47Z</dc:date>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Single-trial event-related potentials with wavelet denoising: method and applications</title>     <link rel="alternate" href="http://hdl.handle.net/2381/3751" />     <author>       <name>Quian Quiroga, R.</name>     </author>     <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2381/3751</id>     <updated>2012-10-15T15:57:01Z</updated>     <published>2009-12-08T16:16:56Z</published>     <summary type="text">Title: Single-trial event-related potentials with wavelet denoising: method and applications Authors: Quian Quiroga, R.</summary>     <dc:date>2009-12-08T16:16:56Z</dc:date>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Water clarification using Moringa oleifera seed coagulant</title>     <link rel="alternate" href="http://hdl.handle.net/2381/3605" />     <author>       <name>Folkard, G.K.</name>     </author>     <author>       <name>Sutherland, J.P.</name>     </author>     <author>       <name>Al-Khalili, R.S.</name>     </author>     <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2381/3605</id>     <updated>2012-10-16T14:00:41Z</updated>     <published>2009-12-08T16:16:49Z</published>     <summary type="text">Title: Water clarification using Moringa oleifera seed coagulant Authors: Folkard, G.K.; Spurgeon, Sarah K.; Edwards, Christopher</summary>     <dc:date>2009-12-08T16:16:42Z</dc:date>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>The application of sliding mode control algorithms to a deisel generator set</title>     <link rel="alternate" href="http://hdl.handle.net/2381/3780" />     <author>       <name>Goh, K.B.</name>     </author>     <author>       <name>Spurgeon, Sarah K.</name>     </author>     <author>       <name>Jones, N.B.</name>     </author>     <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2381/3780</id>     <updated>2012-10-09T15:13:16Z</updated>     <published>2009-12-08T16:16:40Z</published>     <summary type="text">Title: The application of sliding mode control algorithms to a deisel generator set Authors: Goh, K.B.; Spurgeon, Sarah K.; Jones, N.B.</summary>     <dc:date>2009-12-08T16:16:40Z</dc:date>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>A sliding mode scheme for optimal braking and estimation of road/tyre friction detection</title>     <link rel="alternate" href="http://hdl.handle.net/2381/3584" />     <author>       <name>Patel, Nitin</name>     </author>     <author>       <name>Edwards, Christopher</name>     </author>     <author>       <name>Spurgeon, Sarah K.</name>     </author>     <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2381/3584</id>     <updated>2012-10-16T13:33:12Z</updated>     <published>2009-12-08T16:16:38Z</published>     <summary type="text">Title: A sliding mode scheme for optimal braking and estimation of road/tyre friction detection Authors: Patel, Nitin; Edwards, Christopher; Spurgeon, Sarah K. Abstract: Researchers are constantly trying to enhance the safety, driving comfort, traffic circulation and reduce environmental pollution associated with vehicles. Presently there are many on-board controllers available to improve safety and vehicle handling including anti-lock brake systems (ABS), traction control systems (TCS), adaptive intelligent cruise control, active yaw control and active suspension systems. However these control systems only perform to their full potential if they have access to accurate information about the vehicle behaviour in real time. Description: Metadata only entry</summary>     <dc:date>2009-12-08T16:16:38Z</dc:date>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Sliding mode observers for robust fault reconstruction in nonlinear systems</title>     <link rel="alternate" href="http://hdl.handle.net/2381/3585" />     <author>       <name>Tan, Chee Pin</name>     </author>     <author>       <name>Edwards, Christopher</name>     </author>     <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2381/3585</id>     <updated>2012-10-16T13:31:11Z</updated>     <published>2009-12-08T16:16:36Z</published>     <summary type="text">Title: Sliding mode observers for robust fault reconstruction in nonlinear systems Authors: Tan, Chee Pin; Verschure, PFMJ; White, J; Kaur, JS Editors: Wermter, S; Austin, J; Willshaw, D</summary>     <dc:date>2009-12-08T16:16:32Z</dc:date>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>The Structured Singular Value and \ufffd\ufffd-Analysis</title>     <link rel="alternate" href="http://hdl.handle.net/2381/3513" />     <author>       <name>Bates, D.G.</name>     </author>     <author>       <name>Postlethwaite, Ian</name>     </author>     <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2381/3513</id>     <updated>2012-10-16T13:43:25Z</updated>     <published>2009-12-08T16:16:30Z</published>     <summary type="text">Title: The Structured Singular Value and \ufffd\ufffd-Analysis Authors: Bates, D.G.; Postlethwaite, Ian Abstract: We introduce the structured singular value \ufffd\ufffd and discuss its use as an analysis tool for flight control applications. To apply \ufffd\ufffd-analysis tools to flight control law clearance problems, linear fractional transformation (LFT) based uncertainty models must first be generated to capture the effect of uncertain aircraft parameters on the closed-loop system dynamics. The clearance criteria which are most easily addressed with \ufffd\ufffd-analysis are those which are defined in the frequency domain such as the stability margin criterion or the unstable eigenvalue criterion. \ufffd\ufffd-analysis tools which have been developed to address these specific clearance criteria are discussed. Description: This paper was published as Advanced techniques for clearance of flight control laws / (eds.) Christopher Fielding ... [et al.], pp. 37-55. Series: Lecture notes in control and information sciences ; 283.  It is available from http://www.springerlink.com/content/tvnjb87lragl3b5x/.  Doi: 10.1007/3-540-45864-6_3; Metadata only entry</summary>     <dc:date>2009-12-08T16:16:30Z</dc:date>   </entry>   <entry>     <title>Robust fault detection using sliding mode observers</title>     <link rel="alternate" href="http://hdl.handle.net/2381/3597" />     <author>       <name>Edwards, Christopher</name>     </author>     <author>       <name>Tan, Chee Pin</name>     </author>     <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2381/3597</id>     <updated>2012-10-15T15:48:58Z</updated>     <published>2009-12-08T16:16:26Z</published>     <summary type="text">Title: Robust fault detection using sliding mode observers Authors: Edwards, Christopher; Tan, Chee Pin Abstract: The purpose of a Fault Detection & Isolation (FDI) scheme is to generate an alarm when a fault occurs in the system being monitored, and also to identify the nature/location of the fault. Many FDI methods are observer-based: the plant output is compared with the output of an observer designed from a model of the system, and the discrepancy is used to form a so-called residual [9].
